captions.text: Dear Mr. President,

Do you know much about physics? I mean, you're
the President of the United States: a country

with five thousand nuclear weapons, birthplace
of the world's computing and telecommunications

industry, home of the first atomic clock and
creator of the global positioning system.

But chances are, if you just took regular
American high school physics, you don't know

one iota about the science behind these things
(No offense). That's because high school physics

students across most of America are not required
to learn about pretty much any physical phenomena

discovered or explained more recently than
1865. Yes, 1865. That's the year the civil

war ended and well over a decade before Albert
Einstein was even born!

You know what can happen in 150 years, Mr.
President? A lot. Velcro, for one. But let

me list some useful and important ideas of
the last 150 years of physics that aren't

a required part of most standard US high school
physics courses:

Photons. The structure of atoms. The existence
of Antimatter. GPS. Lasers. Transistors. Diodes

and LEDs. Quarks. Chaos Theory. Electron Microscopy.
MRI scanning. The Big Bang. Black Holes. Star

formation. The fact that gravity bends light.
The fact that the universe is expanding. The

Higgs Boson and the weak and strong nuclear
forces and all the rest of quantum mechanics

and relativity and the topic of every single
Nobel Prize in Physics since… always. Basically,
most of the important stuff.

I mean, Mr. President, imagine if history
classes didn't talk about the abolition of

slavery, world wars I or II, the great depression,
the rise of the US as a global superpower,

the cold war or the civil rights movement
or heaven forbid the first African American

President. Or imagine if biology classes didn't
talk about DNA, or hormones, or cell reproduction

or the modern germ theory of disease or ecology.
Or if geologists didn't talk about plate tectonics.

And computer scientists… well… in 1865
a computer was a person who computed your
taxes.

Now, if you were lucky enough to have an ambitious
teacher or take Advanced Placement Physics,

then you might have learned about some of
Einstein's discoveries of 1905! Yes! Current

events! But learning about how Einstein's
work helped set the stage for a century of

amazing developments in our understanding
of the universe is not a part of the standard
curriculum.

So why, Mr. President, am I addressing this
letter to you? Well, you appoint the Secretary

of Education, for one - and I do believe that
high school physics is somewhat related to
education.

Now, maybe your education secretary says,
"ancient physics is already hard to teach

to high schoolers. And you want us to teach
them modern physics which is even harder?!

Students can't really appreciate the beauty
of modern physics without fancy college level

mathematics." RUBBISH. Ever heard of Carl
Sagan? Richard Feynman? Or Neil deGrasse Tyson?

These great men have been 100% committed to
the appreciation and dissemination of the

awesomeness of the universe. And we should
be too. How else are we supposed to foster

and find our future brilliant innovators,
inventors, and explorers? How can we expect

to educate our citizens for the next century
if we don't teach about the last?

And that's not to say that we should ignore
math, either - on the contrary, math is one

of the most beautiful and awesome things in
the universe, especially because it allows
us to understand the universe.

In particular, the last 150 years have borne
fruit to perhaps the most drastic changes

in our understanding of the universe, ever,
and these new ways of thinking and solving

problems should be the centerpiece of an education
in physics.

Between you and me, Mr. President, I think
we'd better start making physics education

more awesome here in the US, otherwise the
next Carl Sagan or Richard Feynman will come

from somewhere with more educational foresight
- maybe even, the Internet.
Sincerely,
A collection of atoms known as Henry

ps you're probably super busy, but if you'd
like to hear about physics education across

the Atlantic, I highly recommend heading over
to Brady's channel, Sixty Symbols, for a perspective
from the UK. I bet you'll enjoy it.

comments.text:
I'm really happy I got to know my high school physics teacher outside of 
school as a friend. I learned more from him in offhand conversation with 
him, and just books he recommended to me, than actual classes. But, that 
seems like a trend in U.S. education. I was exposed to literature (beyond 
bullshit assessments and timed essays, which are ridiculous in a completely 
different fashion) by talking about video games with my English teacher.

The fragments given to us in classes aren't worth anything to exploration 
in fields we find interesting. And the worst part is, because you only 
scratch off a few paint chips from the all-encompassing mural of knowledge 
through these classes, finding something that REALLY interests you becomes 
hard. We have to go into colleges that actually focus on something in order 
to find something we wish to understand. The whole point of public 
education in relativity to academia (that is, softening up all you'll need 
to learn for the big-kid stuff) is made useless by this model because 
things are broken down to the point where there isn't any further interest; 
most of the things people are drawn to in physics, chemistry, philosophy 
and math are "too complex" to be touched upon in high school, and it's a 
damned shame.﻿

comments.text:
I feel that our schools need to start early. In my area, you don't learn 
any math applications (algebra, geometry, etc.) until middle school. MIDDLE 
SCHOOL! The first SIX YEARS of our education is devoted to three concepts: 
counting, addition, and multiplication. I get that six and seven year olds 
aren't incredibly advanced, but they are good at learning and remembering. 
Addition could be mastered within a year without excessive stress on the 
students. That means other concepts can be learned sooner and more time can 
be used for math that actually needs more time. Right now, most high school 
graduates have no more math than PreCalc. PreCalc is when Physics joins 
with math and the connection is made more clear. If we could learn more 
math, we could learn more Physics! Foundations are important. In elementary 
school, the sporadic science lessons boil down to three things: memorize 
what the teacher says, get an A on the quiz, and forget everything. Again, 
no real science until middle school, and even that is vague and 
superficial. There are some who would say that starting early would cause 
stress. Well, spending six years convincing students that education is warm 
and fuzzy and tests don't matter and then tossing them into the 
ultra-competitive world is like sending a chihuahua into the woods and 
expecting it to thrive. The only way to get students to learn the complex 
stuff in high school is to teach them early. Rant finished.﻿

comments.text:
I'd like to preface this comment by saying that I am fourteen and a 
freshman in high school. Also, I had a physical science class last year. 
The textbook got through sixty pages on the nature of light without once 
mentioning the term "photon."

+Lycify Here's the thing: every class you take exists for a reason. It is 
dramatically easier to convince people that you are a credible, 
knowledgeable fountain of lovely, correct opinions if you can write a 
roughly nine paragraph, essay-like piece on America's broken education 
system without committing innumerable crimes against grammar and syntax. 
Your English class is intended for the maintenance of your democracy, 
because if you can't read at least secondary sources on current events and 
preferably primary sources and original research, or if you cannot persuade 
people of your views, you cannot be an effective citizen in a democratic 
society. Similarly, your gym class is meant to increase your health both by 
teaching you how to do physical activity properly and forcing you to do so, 
while at the same time improving your academic performance (I can probably 
dig up some links to support this assertion upon request).
As for the not-at-all challenging curriculum, that's often called "lowest 
common denominator" education. It arises from the fact that students at the 
bottom not passing is something schools and teachers are punished for, but 
students at the middle or top being bored out of their skulls is not. 
Regrettable? Yes. An easy problem to solve? Nope.
Oh, and on the subject of lack of diversity in education: your language 
arts teacher is not even remotely qualified to teach film or computer 
coding. While it would be nice for those things to be taught, the funding 
to make that happen is almost never available.
+LividMinecraft There is actually an extant reason for that language. 
People who speak different languages think in different ways. For instance, 
those whose languages describe keys in the feminine tend to describe them 
as "intricate" and "little", whereas those whose languages describe keys in 
the masculine tend to describe them as "hard" and "jagged." (This also says 
something far beyond the scope of this comment about gender stereotypes.) 
Also, linguistics, like math, can often be an exercise in critical 
thinking. Finally, being able to talk to people who speak other languages 
is kind of important.
+Jonathan St-Yves I'm going to play the devils advocate here. In my school 
district, 4 English credits are required to graduate with an advanced 
diploma. You argue that these help to build up communication skills and 
bolster cultural understanding. However, we don't require music courses, 
even though analyzing the works of Beethoven, Armstrong, and even the 
Beatles would be valuable from a cultural standpoint. We don't require (or, 
in many cases, even offer) film and video courses, even though the works of 
Hitchcock and Kubrick are classic, film is a massive part of our culture, 
and video is an increasingly prevalent medium for the communication of 
ideas. Yes, solid courses in one's native language are necessary for a good 
education in culture and communication, but they are certainly not 
sufficient, and it may be time to ask ourselves if that time could be 
better spent elsewhere.
+Azure I live in the United States. Believe me when I say, you haven't seen 
anything close to our levels of exam-crazy. I had a math class fairly 
recently in which most of what we were taught was how to use the 
calculator. Our standardized tests are largely multiple choice, so to 
simplify a radical, you first enter the radical into your calculator, then 
enter each possible answer, then the smallest answer that matches is 
correct. To solve an equation, you can dispense with all the fancy math; 
just enter each side of the equation into a separate equation in the y= 
menu, hit graph, have the calculator find the intercepts, and you have your 
answer. There's even an app automatically installed on the calculator which 
will, if you input degree and coefficients, helpfully spit out the solution 
to any quadratic you will find on any test, including the standardized one! 
Easy as pie! (Until you get to higher math where the calculator isn't 
nearly so convenient, or have to use the logical reasoning skills you would 
have learned had you actually done the math, or need to build off the 
knowledge that you should have gained but didn't because you weren't doing 
actual math).

comments.text:
+Lycify I agree completely with you. As a 15 year old in Singapore, i 
honestly think that the humanities subject (History, to be exact) is 
completely useless. Not that the things we learn about how World War II 
happened is useless, but the things we are required to write for exams is 
really not related to understanding the events that happened.

In Singapore, we secondary school students are required to take a 
"mandatory" O-Level examination during secondary 4. History is one of the 
subjects that are available to my school to choose for an elective 
humanities subject. We are required to write long essays to explain how or 
why things happened (e.g. What are 2 causes of WW2? Explain your answer). I 
think that the skills we learnt from writing the essay isn't entirely 
useless, but i do think it doesn't encompass the entire idea of "learning 
from past mistakes and to make sure similar mistakes won't happen in the 
future". 

Certainly, i agree that writing about things like that would make you think 
about the wrongdoings of the past, but honestly, most students will not 
give a flying shit about preventing these mistakes, but to write out a 
proper answer that can fetch them 7 marks instead.

I initially thought History would be fun, learning about how Hitler was a 
good leader yet an asshole, but no. They teach us how to write essays, how 
to score as high as possible in exams, don't write this, don't write that 
etc. I have friends who would very willingly throw away their human morals 
and values, just to get good grades and a good job. (p.s. He's really self 
centered and has screwed up morals)

My point is, the entire learning system worldwide is flawed (or at least in 
Singapore). Students only really care about good grades and getting a good 
job in the future, hence MANY students don't give a shit about appreciating 
the things they learn. This applies to ALL other subjects so far, so i 
really think the learning system should be changed into a more learning 
oriented direction, and not examination type of learning. Nothing we learn 
at school right now will ever be appreciated for its awesomeness, and that 
is what i really dislike about the learning system in my country.
p.s. Are there similar cases of exam-crazy students in other countries too? 
I would like to know :)

Thanks for reading :)

comments.text:
> Overall, school has become less of a "Learn what you want to do, and 
become good at it, and help the world by using it" and more of a "Learn 
what we tell you to, and learn less of what you want, even though you will 
not use most of what we have taught you."

School hasn't become that way. Public education was never about teaching 
you what *you*, specifily, need to in order to help you further *your* 
interrests. It was always about teaching you the basics of a little bit of 
everything. That used to be some reading and writing, and some maths. And 
some craftsmanship for the boys, and some needlework for the girls. The 
heavy stuff was done by the rich aristocracy that can afford to spend 
decades studying their interrests in foreign languages, history, material 
sciences, astronomy and so on. Nowdays, we no longer rely on some rich guys 
advancing the sciences, but we still teach a little bit of everything 
before you have to commit to something. How would someone discover that 
they actually love languages if they never even learned a second language? 
So, you force *everybody* to learn a little bit about foreign languages. 
You might already know that you want to become a programmer, but how would 
you know if you really like biology and want to work on protein folding 
simulations or whatever if you don't know the first thing about biology? 
And of course, there are all the people who don't already know what they 
want to do in life. What are they supposed to focus their studies on?

Maybe you just don't like english class that much, and that you don't learn 
new things in that class. Well, there are philosophers, lawyers, 
journalists, advertisers, writers, secretaries, historians, public 
relations managers and political science majors out there that *loved* 
their english classes. The opportunity to practice writing, learn about 
different registers of language, read the modern classics that explore 
everything from politics and nationalism to morality and the challanges of 
everyday life.

School can never be perfect, and your interrests might not be covered. But 
remember that langauge is *ancient*, and programming is *very recent*. 
Schools will adapt, and programming will be picked up by schools sooner or 
later. It's good if you bring up that issue with teachers and other people. 
But just because schools are a little behind the times, or some teachers 
don't do a good job, or you really *hate* a certain class, doesn't mean the 
way schools work are fundamentally wrong. Because school today isn't even 
about teaching you things. Shure, there are the *really* basic things that 
everybody needs. Reading and writing and some maths. But you grow up in 
shool. You get to socialize, you'll get to know how people tick, you get up 
in the moring to do your job, you learn how to work with people, and you 
learn how to learn new things. If you actually remember stuff you learned 
in shool, that's a bonus.

comments.text:
As someone (Australian) who is studying a physics degree wit the intent on 
being a high school physics teacher , let me inform you that I am the only 
student in my year group at my university who will teach with a physics 
degree. All other teachers will hold degrees in chemistry, biology or 
geology. These people will also be allowed to teach physics. Let me assure 
you that these people do not have the capability to explain quantum 
mechanics or relativity to high school students.
I am sorry to inform you Henry, that the problem (at least in Australia), 
is not so much with the education system but with the teachers. Physics 
teachers are currently the most in demand teachers in the NSW school system 
because the general attitude of people with physics degrees is that being a 
teacher is a useless career path. In order to change our education system, 
we need to change our society.﻿

MinutePhysics, I believe you are referring to the wrong authority. Although 
it may seem so, your president barely has a choice over his country. The 
congress is whom you should refer to, or more specifically - the ministry 
of education. The president is equivalent to any other congress member. 
Each has the ability to vote, to suggest, and to express their opinion (in 
order to convince the others to vote the same way he/she does). The only 
reason he is considered different is because Barrack is a representation of 
his country.
Think of it as a kingdom and an empire:
*In kingdoms,* there's is only one king who chooses what to do with what. 
If the king wants to kill every other citizen in his country, he could 
choose to do that as well.
*In empires,* there are multiple people who sit and think and then choose. 
They choose for our lives.  The emperor is merely just a symbol.
The United States and many other democratic societies are most similar to 
empires rather than kingdoms. And regardless, it is easier to get in 
contact with the congress or the ministry of education rather than Obama 
himself.﻿

comments.text:
If you want to see what happens when you try to shove modern physics into a 
two-year high school programme, just come to any high school in Australia 
and have a good laugh. Two years is hardly enough time to teach classical 
physics at any acceptable depth. In the end, it all comes down rote 
learning and essay writing. We used to write pages after pages of nonsense 
about wave-particle duality when we didn't even understand what 
"diffraction" was, but apparently that was not needed to get a good mark. 
In a country like the US or Australia, where the vast majority of 
university-trained professionals are working either in academia or in the 
industry and most high school teachers are woefully underqualified, 
introducing modern physics into high school syllabi will only make a bigger 
mess of the whole thing.﻿
